item.title: Containerized CI Pipeline
item.author: kimarp15@gmail.com (Kim Arpiainen)
item.description:
Its possible to use Docker for building, linting, testing and packaging the project. This way its possible to have the same “pipeline” locally and on the CI server. The local debugging and speed is the most obvious benefit, but it also means that you are not that deeply vendor locked compared to using e.g. Azure DevOps pipeline tasks for each specific step. It will also greatly simplify the pipeline configuration.

Simple example for a build process would be just to build the project and run tests. Below is an example Dockerfile for reference.

# Base layer to copy the sources and run restore.
FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:5.0 AS build-base
WORKDIR /src
COPY . .
RUN dotnet restore HelloWorld.sln

# Run tests and collect coverage
FROM build-base AS test
RUN dotnet test tests/**/*.csproj --logger trx --collect:"XPlat Code Coverage" --results-directory TestResults --no-restore

# Build and publish
FROM build-base AS publish
RUN dotnet publish "src/HelloWorld/HelloWorld.csproj" -c Release -o /app/publish

# Grab the built files from publish layer and copy them over.
# Create the final runtime image
FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/aspnet:5.0-alpine AS final
EXPOSE 80
WORKDIR /app
COPY --from=publish /app/publish .
ENTRYPOINT ["dotnet", "HelloWorld.dll"]

With the example Dockerfile, its possible to test and build the project. However, running basic docker build command does not run the test stage as the final stage does not depend on it. To run the test stage only use the --target flag. docker build --target test -f src/HelloWorld/Dockerfile .

With the target flag its possible to run any stage from the Dockerfile. This helps when you want to run the stage that is failing, for example the unit tests. However, using the --target flag is a bit cumbersome, and what if there is a need to run all stages, or there are multiple stages that should be run separately?

For simplifying the commands we can use Gnu Make. The stages can be added to the Makefile for developer friendly commands.

imageTag = docker-ci:latest
.PHONY: all build test final

all: build test final

build:
  @DOCKER_BUILDKIT=1 docker build -f src/HelloWorld/Dockerfile . --target publish
test:
  @DOCKER_BUILDKIT=1 docker build -f src/HelloWorld/Dockerfile . --target test
final:
  @DOCKER_BUILDKIT=1 docker build -f src/HelloWorld/Dockerfile -t $(imageTag) . --target final

With the Makefile we can now run the stages declared in it with make <stage> e.g. make test. We also have targets all, build and final, where all runs all of the declared stages, build does dotnet publish and final builds the Docker image. Custom tag can be provided by running make final imageTag=<your-tag-here>.

.PHONY targets are targets that do not generate a file with the same name. Thus if you leave it out and create a file with the target name e.g. test, it will not run the stage as it will think its already ran with the message make: 'test' is up to date.

BuildKit is an improved builder for Docker. It is more performant than the default builder as it can run build steps in parallel and add other optimizations. It also has some additional features such as build cache import/export which is not used here. It is currently an opt-in fature and it works only on Linux containers. More information in Docker docs.

As the docs recommend enabling it per command, the DOCKER_BUILDKIT=1 is prepended to each build command in the Makefile. This will enable it per command for each developer, not messing up other Docker configuration and ready to go after getting the source.

Thus far the example project has now build and test stages containerized which hopefully limits the environmental differences between the developers. Using GNU Make added simplicity to the commands, which improves the development workflow. To get benefits from automation too, the same stages should be implemented in CI server. I will use Azure DevOps as an example, but as the stages are ran using Docker, the setup is similar with other solutions too.

Example azure-pipelines.yml

trigger:
- master

pool:
  vmImage: ubuntu-latest

variables:
  DOCKER_BUILDKIT: 1

steps:
- bash: make build
- bash: make test
- bash: make final

That is it. The Azure DevOps pipeline uses simple bash steps, as Docker is installed on the Microsoft Hosted Agents. The exact same pipeline can be debugged locally and the pipeline configuration file remains short and readable. However, to improve the readability on the CI side, descriptions for the steps should be added.

Getting test results from the test stage

With the current configuration, the test step will fail and show the results in stdout. However, now that there is a CI setup in place, it would be good to get the test results visible for the whole project. To do that, the test results need to be exported from the build stage.

The new stage is test-output. This could be used as the target for testing to get the results on each test run.

FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:5.0 AS build-base
WORKDIR /src
COPY . .
RUN dotnet restore HelloWorld.sln

FROM build-base AS test
RUN dotnet test tests/**/*.csproj --logger trx --collect:"XPlat Code Coverage" --results-directory TestResults --no-restore

# Copy test results to empty 'scratch' container.
FROM scratch as test-output
COPY --from=test /src/TestResults/ /

FROM build-base AS publish
RUN dotnet publish "src/HelloWorld/HelloWorld.csproj" -c Release -o /app/publish

FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/aspnet:5.0-alpine AS deploy-base
EXPOSE 80
WORKDIR /app
COPY --from=publish /app/publish .
ENTRYPOINT ["dotnet", "HelloWorld.dll"]

This will copy the output from backend-test stage to an empty container. Using the -output or -o flag we can get the files from the container to the host machine.

imageTag = docker-ci:latest

.PHONY: all test build final

all: test final

build:
	@DOCKER_BUILDKIT=1 docker build -f src/HelloWorld/Dockerfile . --target publish
test:
    @DOCKER_BUILDKIT=1 docker build -f src/HelloWorld/Dockerfile . --target test-output -o TestResults
final:
    @DOCKER_BUILDKIT=1 docker build -f src/HelloWorld/Dockerfile -t $(imageTag) . --target final

To get the test results visible to Azure Devops, the PublishTestResults task is required. Here is the full azure-pipelines.yml configuration.

trigger:
- master

pool:
  vmImage: ubuntu-latest

variables:
  DOCKER_BUILDKIT: 1

steps:
- bash: make build
- bash: make test
- bash: make final
- task: PublishTestResults@2
  inputs:
    testResultsFormat: VSTest
    testResultsFiles: TestResults/*.trx

Closing thoughts

Even with the simple configuration without all BuildKits features, the setup still provides faster and easier debugging and development. It should also be quite easy to change to any other CI provider and thus reduce vendor lock. Of course there are other things to consider before doing that.

As a slight drawback if you want to fully Dockerize the setup and need some outside dependency (e.g. a browser for frontend testing), you have to maintain those images yourself. Or one option would be to run those steps directly on the CI host, as e.g. Microsoft Hosted Agents in Azure DevOps have bunch of useful dependencies pre-installed.

I highly recommend reading the 3 part blog series about the topic by Chris Crone. The environment in the series is for Go development, but it can be applied to other languages and environments as well.

item.title: Development environment in a container with Remote Containers
item.author: kimarp15@gmail.com (Kim Arpiainen)
item.description:
Multiple projects with different development environments are painful. Or the same project developed on two separate machines. Install this and that to get it running. Now the project starts but something is still off. Fix that. Now help your team to get it running too. If you are smart you document your steps. After a while a new developer joins your team, or maybe your own computer breaks down. You have to use precious time to get yet-another-development-environment up and running. Maybe there are things that you forgot to document.

What if we could share our development environment with the other team members to reduce the “works on my machine” -effect and also cut costs by saving time on onboarding and maintenance?

Short introduction to containers

Containers allow developers to package the application, its dependencies and configuration into a container image. It isolates the application from others on a shared operating system. The containers run on top of a container host (for example Docker) and the host runs on the OS. As the OS is shared by the containers, they have significantly smaller footprint compared to traditional virtual machines. Source

Development containers to the rescue

Development environment can be shared with a virtual machine, and sometimes it is the better option. However, as the virtual machine image requires to package and run the entire operating system, it is burdensome to share with others and the performance is lower. The resources for the VM are reserved on startup instead of using only what is needed. It is also quite likely that developers will start to have “snowflake” boxes that have different packages and package versions.

To have a bit more dependencies than this blog site which is used later as an example, lets pick a “default” Angular project to make our case. The development environment should have NodeJS, Angular CLI and Chrome (for Karma tests) installed. Creating a virtual machine just for sharing that environment is overkill. There is way too much packaged into it, not to mention the resources wasted to run virtualized OS on top of your host OS just to be able to run NodeJS, AngularCLI and Chrome. So using a container seems to be a better alternative.

Development containers can be a bit different than the small containers used in production. When the container image is only used for development purposes, there is no need to keep them as tiny as possible. You can install whatever tools you need as its only for development. For the image base you can start with the “regular” ones instead of Alpine or slim versions. You also rarely need to rebuild the image, only when the tools change. When you need to install a tool for development you can either install it directly inside the container (maybe you only need it for the current thing you are working on) or include it in the Dockerfile for the whole team to enjoy. (There is also postCreateCommand-setting in the devcontainer.json for e.g. installing packages).

Sharing with the team is easy, you keep the Dockerfile versioned in the git repository and each developer builds their own image based on it. You don’t have to commit and set up Docker registeries at this point. To keep the packages unified across environments, its a good idea to pin specific package and image versions you are using instead of :latest or :lts.

Due to the isolated nature of the containers and images, you can remove them after they are no longer needed and all the project specific dependencies are gone. Working with multiple projects becomes easier as all the packages and versions are isolated in own environments.

Okay cool, nothing new here. I already know what containers have to offer. The problem is that me and/or my team have limited knowledge about Docker. We cannot start using them without investing a lot of time and effort on competence development.

Enter VSCode with Remote - Containers plugin. It allows for a pleasant development experience with minimal Docker knowledge. You can use Microsofts provided samples as a base image or your own Dockerfile.

{
    "name": "Personal blog",
    "build": {
        "dockerfile": "Dockerfile",
    },
    "forwardPorts": [
        1313
    ],
    "mounts": [
        "source=${localWorkspaceFolder},target=/src,type=bind,consistency=cached"
    ],
    "extensions": [
        "vscodevim.vim",
    ],
    "containerUser": "hugo"
}

This is the devcontainer.json file I use for this blog. With a couple of lines of configuration, I can start a VSCode instance inside the container, forwarding the ports and automatically installing the extensions I want. I can also share this with others along with the dockerfile to share the environments.

Development Dockerfile for this blog 
FROM klakegg/hugo:0.78.2-ext-debian

WORKDIR /src

# Create group hugo and user to said group named hugo. 
# -m switch creates home directory /home/hugo which is needed for devcontainer
RUN groupadd -r hugo && useradd -m -g hugo hugo

ENTRYPOINT [ "shell" ]

Both the Dockerfile and the devcontainer.json file are stored in .devcontainer folder which is the convention.

Typing >Remote containers to the command palette shows the available options. To start VSCode inside the devcontainer, make sure you have the prequisites in check and start by selecting Remote-Containers: Rebuild and Reopen in Container from the command menu. When you are running VSCode inside the container, you can rebuild the container to apply changes to your Dockerfile / devcontainer configuration. If you want to exit the container and return to “normal”, select Remote-Containers: Reopen Locally as shown in the picture.

After that massive introduction that is pretty much it. If the setup is done correctly you are running VSCode inside the container. (To be precise, VSCode is still ran on the host and it communicates with VSCode server inside the container). VSCode handles the starting automatically and most of the time you don’t even notice anything different. Except now you have isolated, documented and shareable development environment. It is also possible to connect to a container in a remote host!

Closing thoughts

Docker and containers are nothing new under the sun and development environments as well as production environments have been packaged into containers for a while now. The real value is in the VSCode integration. Working inside a development container seems to “just work”. You can start reaping the benefits of isolated and unified development containers without spending a lot of time on learning the specific Docker workflows and commands.

See the “Remote containers tutorial” and “Advanced containers” for more information.

item.title: Simplifying Test Setup with Fluent Builder
item.author: kimarp15@gmail.com (Kim Arpiainen)
item.description:
One of the many difficult things in software development is unit testing. Tests should be simple enough so that it’s easy to see and verify what is being tested. They should also be adaptive enough not to become too big of a burden to maintain alongside the production code. Not to mention actually testing something meaningful. This post focuses on the first phase of unit testing, the Arrange-phase. In case you are not familiar with AAA (“Arrange, Act, Assert” pattern), you can read more here.

One way to setup test objects is to use setters or object initializer syntax to populate the values in each test. Lets say that we have 10 tests for the customer written in the following way:

[Fact]
public void Customer_WithValidData_ThenSomething() {
    var customer = new Customer();
    customer.Name = "Jon";
    customer.Age = 25;
    customer.Email = "something@something.com";
    // rest of the test
}

This is quite basic setup phase. We can assume that Name, Age and Email are all required properties for a valid customer. It makes sense to refactor the Customer class constructor to have those three parameters so that its impossible to create customer without these values.

After the constructor change, there are 10 compile errors in our Customer tests. At the same time the setters could be made private, so that raises the compilation error count even more. To fix this problem in our tests, we can extract a method for CreateValidCustomer and use that for object creation.

public Customer CreateValidCustomer() {
    return new Customer("Jon", 25, "something@something.com");
}

I guess that in most cases the pitfall from first example is avoided and some sort of CreateTestData method is in place from the beginning. It’s a lot better option as we control the object creation in a single place. That means that if the class API changes, we only need to update one place to reflect those changes. This way we can avoid breaking the tests in multiple places.

However, for thorough testing you will need different variations of objects. For that you probably have a class that contains a few methods for creating test objects. Examples could be CreateValidCustomer and CreateInvalidCustomer. This is usually referred as the “Object Mother”. The drawback of the Object Mother is that it’s hard to handle the different permutations required for our tests.

This is where the Fluent Builder can help. You can easily define the target state for the object.

// This is test specific code which lies in the test project
// not referenced nor part of production code
public class CustomerBuilder {

    private string _name = "Jon"; // you can have defaults here
    private int _age;
    private string _email;

    public CustomerBuilder() {
        // or if you prefer to explicitly set the defaults in the constructor
        _age = 25;
        _email = "something@something.com";
    }

    public CustomerBuilder WithName(string name) {
        _name = name;
        return this;
    }

    public CustomerBuilder WithAge(int age) {
        _age = age;
        return this;
    }

    public Customer Build() {
        return new Customer(_name, _age, _email);
    }
}

With the Fluent Builder setup we can now easily create different types of customers.

    var customerWithInvalidName = new CustomerBuilder()
        .WithName("-")
        .Build();

    var tooYoungCustomerWithValidName = new CustomerBuilder()
        .WithName("Jon")
        .WithAge(1)
        .Build();

Now we have a way for creating different variations from the Customer class for our testing needs. The builder will also make the object creation clear and declarative. In most cases we still need the default valid customer. For that you can define some sensible default values and call new CustomerBuilder().Build().

One could argue that tests with unique test data needs are better to write inline within the test using constructor, and the common cases are covered with the Object Mother. That leads us straight back to the first example. If we would add e.g. Address property, we could hopefully fix the old tests with a default value, thus no changes are required in the client code.

In case you have multiple tests where you need the same configuration for a customer, e.g. GenericInvalidCustomer, you can combine the creation method and Fluent Builder pattern by adding the method in the builder class. For really complex object graphs you could even combine other classes builders/object mothers to build up the customer. E.g. customer.Address = AddressMother.ValidAddress().

Summary

The Fluent Builder is a great pattern for unit testing. Even though it might seem like too much hassle, it is quick and easy to implement. When you need to change a property, just add a few lines of boilerplate code. That being said, I definitely do not recommend writing a Fluent Builder for every class in the system. I would start with a basic creation method and adjust as necessary. Whatever is the easiest to maintain.

item.title: Avoid Logic in Setters
item.author: kimarp15@gmail.com (Kim Arpiainen)
item.description:
Its quite common in business to have requirements that when A happens, B needs to happen too. In the following imaginary example, the requirement is to increment the car owner count each time the owner changes. One way to implement it is to increment the counter in the setter. That way the developers don’t have to remember to increment the counter each time owner is changed, updating the property is enough. In a bigger project this could be a domain event e.g. CarOwnerChangedEvent and the handler would take care of this. To keep things simple, we just increment the counter.

public class Car
{
    private Owner _owner;
    public int Id { get; set; }
    public int OwnerCount {get; private set;}
    public Owner Owner {
        get {
            return _owner;
        }
        set {
            OwnerCount++;
            _owner = value;
        }
    }
}

class Client {
    public void CarSoldToNewOwner(int carId, Owner newOwner)
    {
        var car = GetCarById(carId);
        car.Owner = newOwner;
    }

    public Car GetCarById(int id)
    {
        return _context.Cars
            .Include(x => x.Owner)
            .FirstOrDefault(x => x.Id == id);
    }
}

public class DemoContext : DbContext
{
    public DemoContext(DbContextOptions<DemoContext> options) : base(options){ }
    public DbSet<Car> Cars { get; set; }
    public DbSet<Owner> Owners { get; set; }
}

And of course we’ve included a test case to prove that it works correctly.

[Fact]
public void Car_OnOwnerChange_IncrementsOwnerCount()
{
    var car = new Car();
    car.Owner = new Owner("owner");
    Assert.Equal(1, car.OwnerCount);
}

Updating the Car object

Entity Framework (EF) Core is used in the example to handle persistence for us. Now the day comes that an old car that was already in the system is sold to a new owner. CarSoldToNewOwner is called and car data is fetched from the database, EF creates a Car object for us and we change the owner. The GetCarById is a simple read-only query, it gets the car with the correct Id and loads the Owner data along with it.

The problems arise when the saved entity is fetched from the database by our ORM. Entity framework needs to fetch the data from the database and construct objects for us to handle. The problem with setters is that ORMs can use them when creating objects. Due to wrongly configured backing field in the Car class (wrong being no configuration at all), EF will call the Owner setter in the Car class when retrieving the object in GetCarById. Thus the CarSoldToNewOwner will increment the owner counter by two instead of one, once after the read and second time by our business logic. This is definitely not obvious behavior from reading the code and thus a hard bug to track. GetCarById is just a simple read-only query. Although the convention for a backing field is followed, navigation properties require additional configuration.

Fixing the issue

Personally I would fix this issue by moving the logic away from the setter, maybe even having the setter as private and have a ChangeOwner(newOwner) method in the Car class that increments the counter. The API becomes more clear and I’m expecting additional processing as I’m calling a method instead of a property setter. Also if we would like to include some validation to the owner change, like a null check, it would not make much sense if the setter throws an ArgumentNullException. In my opinion a separate method follows the Principle of least astonishment better than the property setter.

There are definitely cases where having the increment in the setter is the best option. Could be for example a legacy system with dozens of references to car.Owner = newOwner and we need to get the business requirement filled. Or bunch of other reasons. To get the example working as expected in EF core, following configuration is required.

protected override void OnModelCreating(ModelBuilder modelBuilder)
{
    var navigation = modelBuilder.Entity<Car>()
        .Metadata.FindNavigation(nameof(Car.Owner));

    navigation.SetPropertyAccessMode(PropertyAccessMode.Field);
}

With this configuration, EFs object creation does not touch the setter anymore and the owner count is incremented only in our code. It uses the provided backing field _owner instead of the Owner property.

Summary

Although I only tested this behavior on EF core, my guess is that the problem with setters applies to other ORMs as well, one way or another. Personally I prefer the first fix, where the logic is encapsulated to a method. It is more clear for the API consumer, does not require any additional configuration for the entities and the team does not have to worry about the weird cases where the problem surfaces.

If you need to take the second route with the additional configuration, double check that you have integration tests that include EF in the mix. You can find one example here. Obviously its always good to have the integration tests, even when going with the recommended solution.
